facts.text: The appellant is a Jute Mill.
There was a dispute pending before an Industrial Tribunal between a number of jute mills in West Bengal and their employees, and the appellant was a party to that dispute.

During the pendency of that dispute, the appellant laid-off the respondent who was an employee in the ration shop maintained by the appellant from July 19, 1954, as rationing of food-stuff came to an end from July 10, 1954.
The reason for the lay-off was that the ration shop was closed following the end of rationing. This resulted in the staff in that shop becoming surplus.
Consequently, nine persons were selected for retrenchment on the principle of last come first go, and the respondent was one of them.
The appellant applied under s. 33 of the Act to the Industrial Tribunal for permission to retrench the respondent along with others.

Shortly before the application under s. 33, the respondent applied under s. 33-A of the Act. His case was that there was no reason to make any retrenchment on account of the closure of the ration shop; he was longer in service than others retained; principle of last come first go not followed; laid-off as active union worker not in good books of appellant. Prayed for full wages and amenities since lay-off (which was retrenchment) and reinstatement.

The Industrial Tribunal concluded that the lay-off was justified because of the closure of the ration shop and gave permission to the appellant to retrench the respondent on the principle of last come first go.
The respondent appealed to the Labour Appellate Tribunal. He did not urge no necessity for retrenchment; urged Industrial Tribunal wrong in holding principle of last come first go followed.

The Appellate Tribunal concluded respondent in service much longer than others retained; principle violated. Appeal allowed; permission to retrench refused; respondent reinstated without break in continuity; order laying off/discharging from July 19, 1954 set aside.
Appellant came to Supreme Court; granted special leave limited to whether reinstatement order can be made under s.33A.

legal_issues.text: Whether an order of reinstatement can be made on an application under s. 33-A of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

petitioner_arguments.text: Learned counsel for the appellant wanted to argue that this was not a case of discharge or dismissal but of lay-off.

respondent_arguments.text: There was no reason to make any retrenchment; respondent longer in service than retained workers; last come first go not followed; laid-off due to union activity.
Before Appellate Tribunal: Industrial Tribunal wrong in holding last come first go followed.

court_reasoning.text: A complaint under s. 33-A is as good as a reference under s. 10; tribunal adjudicates as if dispute referred/pending; has all powers including to order reinstatement in proper cases where dismissal/discharge in breach of s.33.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal has power to order reinstatement under s.33A if complaint of dismissal/discharge in breach of s.33.

court_reasoning.text: Did not permit appellant to argue lay-off not discharge/dismissal as special leave limited to the question.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appeal limited; on that question, appeal fails.

holdings.text: Tribunal has power to order reinstatement on complaint under s.33A if employee dismissed/discharged in breach of s.33.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: s.33-A complaint treated as reference under s.10; breach of s.33 allows reinstatement.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; upheld Labour Appellate Tribunal's order of reinstatement under s.33A as tribunal has such power.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; maintains reinstatement to respondent.

key_quotes.text: a complaint under s. 33-A of the Act is as good as a reference under s. 10 of the Act and the tribunal has all the powers to deal with it as it would have in dealing with a reference under s. 10.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on powers under s.33A.

key_quotes.text: it is certainly within its power to order reinstatement on such complaint, if the complaint is that the employee has been dismissed or discharged in breach of s. 33.
key_quotes.speaker: court
